title: Pearson Equations for Discrete Orthogonal Polynomials: II. Generalized Charlier, Meixner and Hahn of type I cases
summary: This paper focuses on the Cholesky factorization of moment matrices for generalized Charlier, Meixner, and Hahn discrete orthogonal polynomials. The authors derive alternative derivations of Laguerre-Freud relations and find third-order and second-order nonlinear ordinary differential equations for recursion coefficients.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of mathematical techniques, including Cholesky factorization and Laguerre-Freud relations, to analyze the properties of discrete orthogonal polynomials.
research_outcomes: The authors derive new expressions for recursion coefficients and find relationships between them. They also show that the moment matrix can be expressed in terms of a Cholesky factorization.

title: The Role of Spin(9) in Octonionic Geometry
summary: This paper reviews the role of Spin(9) in octonionic geometry, discussing its interactions with geometries related to octonions and its applications in various areas. The authors provide a survey of their recent work on Spin(9) and octonionic geometry, including the construction of the canonical 8-form Φ Spin(9) and its analogies with quaternionic geometry.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of geometric and algebraic methods to study the properties of Spin(9) structures and their applications in octonionic geometry.
research_outcomes: The authors provide a comprehensive review of the role of Spin(9) in octonionic geometry, including its interactions with geometries related to octonions and its applications in various areas. They also present new results on the construction of the canonical 8-form Φ Spin(9) and its analogies with quaternionic geometry.
sources_of_inspiration: J. Baez extensive Bulletin AMS paper on octonions [Bae02]

title: Generalizing Cographs to 2-Cographs
summary: This paper generalizes the concept of cographs to 2-cographs, which are graphs where every connected induced subgraph has a disconnected complement. The authors show that 2-cographs can be recursively defined and are closed under induced minors.
methodology: The authors use graph theory and combinatorial methods to define and study 2-cographs.
research_outcomes: The paper provides a characterization of the class of non-2-cographs for which every proper induced minor is a 2-cograph, and shows that there are finitely many such graphs. It also corrects a previous result on the characterization of when the complement of a 2-connected graph is 2-connected.

title: Joint impacts of media, vaccination and treatment on an epidemic Filippov model with application to COVID-19
summary: This paper proposes a non-smooth SIR Filippov system to investigate the impacts of media coverage, vaccination, and treatment on the spread of an infectious disease. The model incorporates both the number of infected population and its changing rate as the switching condition for implementing control measures.
methodology: The proposed model is a hybrid dynamic system that includes impulsive systems, nonsmooth continuous systems, and Filippov systems to investigate the impacts of various treatment strategies on the dynamical behavior of epidemic models.
research_outcomes: The study finds effective switching containment strategies for infectious diseases by choosing appropriate implementation time and strength for media coverage, vaccination, and treatment measures.

title: Factors of Alternating Convolution of the Gessel Numbers
summary: This paper explores the relationship between Gessel numbers and super Catalan numbers, providing a close connection through alternating convolution. The authors use new sums to prove divisibility by  rac{1}{2}S(n,r) for all non-negative integers n and positive integers r.
methodology: The paper employs combinatorial methods, using binomial formulas and symmetry of binomial coefficients to derive relationships between Gessel numbers and super Catalan numbers.
research_outcomes: The authors establish a close relationship between Gessel's numbers P (n, r) and super Catalan numbers S(n, r), showing that an alternating convolution of the Gessel numbers is always divisible by  rac{1}{2}S(n,r).

title: Sequential Bayesian Analysis of Multivariate Count Data
summary: This paper develops a new class of dynamic multivariate Poisson count models, referred to as multivariate Poisson-scaled beta (MPSB) models. The MPSB model allows for serial dependence in the counts as well as dependence across multiple series with a random common environment. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this paper.
methodology: The methodology involves developing a Bayesian hierarchical model of the form (Y jt |λ j , θ t ) ∼ P ois(λ j θ t ), where λ j is the rate specific to the jth series and θ t represents the effects of the random common environment modulating λ j.
research_outcomes: The paper introduces a new class of dynamic multivariate Poisson count models, referred to as multivariate Poisson-scaled beta (MPSB) models. The MPSB model allows for serial dependence in the counts as well as dependence across multiple series with a random common environment.

title: An all speed second order IMEX relaxation scheme for the Euler equations
summary: This paper presents an implicit-explicit finite volume scheme for the Euler equations, focusing on a Suliciu type relaxation model to simplify the non-linear structure of the equations. The proposed scheme is positivity preserving and asymptotic preserving towards the incompressible Euler equations.
methodology: The paper uses an implicit-explicit finite volume scheme with a Suliciu type relaxation model, which simplifies the non-linear structure of the Euler equations.
research_outcomes: The proposed scheme is positivity preserving and asymptotic preserving towards the incompressible Euler equations.

title: Uniqueness in a Navier-Stokes-nonlinear-Schr"odinger model of superfluidity
summary: This paper deals with the problem of uniqueness of local-in-time weak solutions to a model of superfluidity governed by the nonlinear Schrödinger equation (NLS) coupled with the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations (NSE). The authors prove a weak-strong type uniqueness theorem for these weak solutions, showing that a strong solution is unique in the class of weak solutions. This result has implications for the study of superfluidity and the behavior of normal Helium liquid.
methodology: The authors use a combination of mathematical techniques, including Sobolev spaces and energy estimates, to prove the uniqueness theorem.
research_outcomes: The paper establishes a weak-strong type uniqueness theorem for local-in-time weak solutions to a model of superfluidity. This result has implications for the study of superfluidity and the behavior of normal Helium liquid.

title: Efficient methods for the estimation of the multinomial parameter for the two-trait group testing model
summary: This paper presents efficient methods for estimating the multinomial parameter in a two-trait group testing model. The authors show that finding the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) is equivalent to maximizing a multinomial likelihood with a restricted parameter space, and develop an EM algorithm-based approach to solve this problem. They also present two additional closed-form estimators, one based on the method of moments and another as a shrinkage estimator.
methodology: The authors use a combination of mathematical derivations and numerical methods to develop their efficient estimation methods. Specifically, they employ an EM algorithm-based approach to maximize the multinomial likelihood under the restricted parameter space.
research_outcomes: The paper presents three main results: (1) the equivalence between finding the MLE for the two-trait group testing problem and maximizing a multinomial likelihood with a restricted parameter space, (2) an EM algorithm-based approach to solve this problem, and (3) two additional closed-form estimators.

title: OSCILLATIONS AND ASYMPTOTIC CONVERGENCE FOR A DELAY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATION MODELING PLATELET PRODUCTION
summary: This paper analyzes the existence of oscillating solutions and asymptotic convergence for a nonlinear delay differential equation modeling platelet production. The authors propose a new age-structured model of megakaryopoiesis, focusing on the differentiation pathway from hematopoietic stem cells to progenitors to megakaryocytes, including the role of thrombopoietin (TPO). They reduce the model to a scalar nonlinear delay differential equation on the platelet count and prove its unique steady state is locally asymptotically stable. The authors also determine a sufficient and necessary condition for the existence of oscillating solutions.
methodology: The authors use mathematical modeling, specifically age-structured models and delay differential equations, to analyze the dynamics of platelet production.
research_outcomes: The paper provides a new model for megakaryopoiesis, which is locally asymptotically stable. It also determines a sufficient and necessary condition for the existence of oscillating solutions.

title: Conformal metrics on $\ßr^{2m}$ with constant Q-curvature
summary: This paper studies conformal metrics on R^{2m} with constant Q-curvature, particularly in the case of negative or zero curvature. The authors provide existence results and asymptotic behavior at infinity for solutions to the equation.
methodology: The authors use a combination of analytical and geometric methods, including the maximum principle, Jensen's inequality, and Liouville-type theorems.
research_outcomes: The paper provides existence results for solutions to the equation with negative or zero curvature, as well as asymptotic behavior at infinity. The authors also classify all solutions to the equation in arbitrary even dimension.

title: Convex and Non-convex Regularization Methods for Spatial Point Processes Intensity Estimation
summary: This paper deals with feature selection procedures for spatial point processes intensity estimation. It proposes regularized versions of estimating equations based on Campbell theorem derived from two classical functions: Poisson likelihood and logistic regression likelihood. The methods are designed to ensure consistency, sparsity, and asymptotic normality.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of statistical and machine learning techniques to develop new methods for spatial point processes intensity estimation.
research_outcomes: The proposed methods are shown to be consistent, sparse, and asymptotically normal. They are also compared with existing methods in simulation studies and applied to tropical forestry datasets.

title: Hybrid Confidence Intervals for Informative Uniform Asymptotic Inference After Model Selection
summary: This paper proposes a new type of confidence interval, called hybrid selective inference (HySI), for correct asymptotic inference after model selection. The HySI approach combines techniques from selective and post-selection inference literatures to yield a short confidence interval across a wide range of data realizations.
methodology: The paper proposes a new class of hybrid CIs that aims to draw on the complementary informativeness strengths of selective and PoSI CIs. The HySI approach relaxes the conditional coverage requirement of standard selective CIs to produce CIs that are unconditionally valid.
statistics: standard uniform laws of large numbers and central limit theorems (CLTs)
research_outcomes: The paper establishes the uniform asymptotic validity of the HySI CIs, which can be applied to many examples such as inference in a linear regression model selected by LASSO with randomized cross-validation.

title: An alternative approach on the singular metric on a vector bundle
summary: This paper provides an alternative definition for the singular Hermitian metric on a vector bundle, discussing its applications and properties. The research focuses on complex geometry, specifically the Griffiths and Nakano positivity of the singular metric.
methodology: The authors use a combination of mathematical techniques from complex geometry, including Finsler geometry and Hermitian metrics.
research_outcomes: The paper establishes an alternative definition for the singular Hermitian metric on a vector bundle, providing new insights into its properties and applications. The research outcomes include a deeper understanding of the Griffiths and Nakano positivity of the singular metric.

title: Characterization of γ-factors: the Asai case
summary: This paper characterizes Asai γ-factors for smooth irreducible representations of GL_n(E) and establishes their stability property under twists by highly ramified characters. The characterization is achieved through a local-to-global argument, using the Grundwald-Wang theorem and the global Langlands correspondence.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of local and global methods to establish the characterization of Asai γ-factors. Specifically, it employs the local Langlands correspondence, tensor induction, and the global functional equation.
research_outcomes: The main results of this paper are the characterization of Asai γ-factors for smooth irreducible representations of GL_n(E) and their stability property under twists by highly ramified characters.

title: Generators and presentations for direct and wreath products of monoid acts
summary: This paper investigates the preservation of properties under direct and wreath products of monoid acts, specifically focusing on finite generation and presentability. The authors provide characterizations for when these properties are preserved in both constructions, with a focus on diagonal acts.
methodology: The methodology involves using presentations and congruences to study the preservation of properties under direct and wreath products of monoid acts.
research_outcomes: The authors provide several key results, including characterizations for when diagonal acts are finitely generated or presented. They also show that these properties are preserved by direct products.

title: Characterizations of Adjoint Sobolev Embedding Operators for Inverse Problems
summary: This paper collects and generalizes various characterizations of the adjoint Sobolev embedding operator E * s, which plays a crucial role in inverse problems. The authors aim to establish a common reference point for researchers and students by providing rigorous mathematical proofs and discussing different approaches to dealing with E * s.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of variational representations, boundary value problems, Fourier and wavelet transforms, and singular value decompositions to characterize the adjoint Sobolev embedding operator E * s.
research_outcomes: The authors provide a comprehensive overview of different approaches to characterizing E * s, including its role in inverse problems and its connection to differential equations. They also discuss the importance of proper discretizations and efficient implementation of E * s.

title: Singular spherical maximal operators on a class of degenerate two-step nilpotent Lie groups
summary: This paper proves the boundedness of the singular spherical maximal operator on a class of degenerate two-step nilpotent Lie groups, specifically for d ≥ 4 and p > (d-1)/(d-2). The result is obtained by reducing the estimates to oscillatory integral operators.
methodology: The authors use Fourier analysis and harmonic functions to prove the boundedness of the maximal operator. They reduce the problem to a series of lemmas, which are then used to establish the desired inequality.
research_outcomes: The paper establishes the boundedness of the singular spherical maximal operator on a class of degenerate two-step nilpotent Lie groups for d ≥ 4 and p > (d-1)/(d-2).

title: Liouville theorems to system of elliptic differential inequalities on the Heisenberg group
summary: This paper establishes Liouville theorems for a system of elliptic differential inequalities on the Heisenberg group, with no mention or use of machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The authors apply three different test functions to prove the nonexistence results in three different domains of the Heisenberg group.
research_outcomes: The paper proves that certain systems of elliptic differential inequalities have no locally integrable solutions on the Heisenberg group.

title: A Characterization of One-component Inner Functions
summary: This paper presents a characterization of one-component inner functions in terms of the location of their zeros and associated singular measures. The authors provide descriptions and examples of one-component inner functions, answering several questions posed by J. Cima and R. Mortini.
methodology: The authors use Hall's lemma and a stopping time argument to prove their results.
research_outcomes: The paper provides a characterization of one-component inner functions, answers several questions posed by J. Cima and R. Mortini, and shows that some one-component inner functions might be bad-behaving in several ways.

title: Rough Basin Boundaries in High Dimension: Can We Classify Them Experimentally?
summary: This paper investigates the properties of rough basin boundaries in high-dimensional systems, specifically focusing on their classification and fractal dimension. The authors argue that a known condition for roughness holds for high-dimensional bistable systems with a unique non-attracting chaotic set embedded in their basin boundaries. They provide a formula for the co-dimension of the rough basin boundary and discuss its implications for predictability and global instability.
methodology: The authors use numerical computations to determine the fractal dimension of the boundary, reproducing the condition for roughness in a general setting and providing dimension formulae for rough boundaries.
research_outcomes: The study finds that rough basin boundaries can be classified experimentally using the cross-boundary Lyapunov exponent and partial information dimension. The authors also discuss the implications of their findings for predictability and global instability in high-dimensional systems.

title: k-Spectra of c-Balanced Words
summary: This paper investigates the properties and cardinalities of k-spectra in binary words, particularly for strictly balanced and c-balanced words. The authors explore various questions related to recognition and reconstruction of scattered factors and k-spectra, providing new results and insights into their structure.
methodology: The paper employs combinatorial and algebraic techniques to analyze the properties of k-spectra in binary words. It uses Parikh matrices and other mathematical tools to derive new results on the cardinalities and structures of scattered factors and k-spectra.
research_outcomes: The authors provide several key findings, including bounds on the cardinalities of k-spectra for strictly balanced words and c-balanced words. They also investigate the question of reconstructing words from their k-spectra in specific cases.

title: Sampling bipartite graphs with given vertex degrees and fixed edges and non-edges
summary: This paper focuses on the problem of sampling a bipartite graph with given vertex degrees, where a set of edges and non-edges is fixed. The authors propose an extension to the Curveball algorithm, which generates approximate samples at random. They show that repeated k-swaps of lengths 4 ≤ k ≤ 2 − 2 are sufficient for ergodic sampling chains.
methodology: The authors use a Markov chain approach, specifically the Curveball algorithm, to generate approximate samples of bipartite graphs with fixed vertex degrees and edges/non-edges. They also introduce k-swaps as an alternative method.
research_outcomes: The paper presents several results on the ergodicity of sampling chains for bipartite graphs with fixed vertex degrees and edges/non-edges. The authors show that repeated k-swaps are sufficient for ergodic sampling chains, improving previous results by Erdős et al.

title: New exact wave solutions to the space-time fractional-coupled Burgers equations and the space-time fractional foam drainage equation
summary: This paper presents new exact wave solutions to the space-time fractional-coupled Burgers equations and the space-time fractional foam drainage equation using the generalized (G′/G)-expansion method. The method is effective in obtaining closed-form solutions for non-linear fractional differential equations, but it does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence techniques.
methodology: The generalized (G′/G)-expansion method is used to obtain new exact wave solutions to the space-time fractional-coupled Burgers equations and the space-time fractional foam drainage equation. The method involves a series of steps, including the transformation of the differential equation into an ordinary differential equation, integration, and the determination of arbitrary constants.
research_outcomes: New exact wave solutions are obtained for the space-time fractional-coupled Burgers equations and the space-time fractional foam drainage equation. The results show that the generalized (G′/G)-expansion method is effective in obtaining closed-form solutions for non-linear fractional differential equations.

title: On the computation of torus link homology
summary: This paper introduces a new method for computing triply graded link homology, particularly well-adapted to torus links. The authors provide an exact answer for all n and verify conjectures of Gorsky et al relating homology of torus links with Hilbert schemes.
methodology: The authors use a new method based on Rouquier complexes and Hochschild cohomology to compute triply graded link homology.
research_outcomes: The paper provides an exact answer for the triply-graded homology of (n, n) torus links and verifies conjectures of Gorsky et al.
